elements.text:
Thanks to everyone who participated in this confidential survey. Some reactions from participants:


>> I was surprised at the number & types of positions that were $200k+. <<


>> the lower end of the pay range didn't surprise me as much bc i've been there, unfortunately. but i am flabbergasted at my (new-to-me) potential ceiling. 

i was telling my wife i appreciated how the results weren't presented in aggregate but individually, which gave me a better idea of how roles and expectations fit the salaries presented. and showed me a clearer path forward to get where i want to go. <<


>> I was surprised by how much you can make in the industry. I think I had internalized the stereotype that writing/content doesn't make you much money so that was great to see. <<
 

>> My first reaction: I need to ask for a raise or start looking for a new job =D <<


>> I think the most amazing thing was the spread of salary ranges across seemingly similar roles and numbers of direct reports. … My biggest takeaway though is that there is still soooo much money to be made in content so I shouldn't sell myself short. <<


>> It was really insightful. And it really highlights that different organizations value content differently. I definitely need to study it closer as I plan my future. <<


>> Honestly it was really encouraging to see how well we can do in content if we rise to senior roles in good orgs. I still have a lot to learn to get there, but your list was motivating. <<


A number of participants were surprised by the variations in compensation, which ran from $47k to a few seven-figure packages.

There was a concentration of roles from $100k to $250k, including many with bonuses and equity (shared ownership of a company). Nearly all of the jobs can be done 100% remotely.

Note: I won’t be sharing the salary survey results publicly, because the info was collected on the understanding of confidentiality so participants would be transparent about their names, company names, etc. I did that because I get better fidelity as someone who helps companies set compensation — they need to know what relevant companies pay (not what random companies pay; they don't care about competing against crappy companies). I also don’t believe that cheaping out helps good employers hire and retain well, so I focus on the higher end of earnings.

text: did someone say salary? here's some data that might be helpful. <https://superpath.co/blog/content-marketing-salary-report>

attachments.fallback: Your Content Career Headquarters: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters
attachments.text: The average content marketing salary is $93,725. Check out our salary report for more detailed data on job titles, experience and pay discrepancies.
attachments.title: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters

text: Worth noting that the results of the confidential survey I did revealed significantly better earnings than the Superpath compensation survey did. Why: I work in tech/startups and know a good number of high earners in content, which is where many of the participants work.

elements.text: Worth noting that the results of the confidential survey I did revealed significantly better earnings than the Superpath compensation survey did. Why: I work in tech/startups and know a good number of high earners in content, which is where many of the participants work.

text: Relatedly, many high earners don't participate in anonymous surveys, simply because they often already know that they earn more than peers. They'd be more disposed to participate in a survey like mine, because I help highlight potential avenues for them to make more — as you rise in earnings, you have fewer options vs. folks who make less, because there are fewer employers that pay really well.
